data.text: Introduction
1.1. The Trust recognises its responsibilities for the provision of telephony and mobile communications solutions.

1.2. The aim of this policy is to inform all staff of the Trust expectations regarding the use telephony and mobile communications devices provided by the Trust, and to ensure staff are aware of their managerial and operational responsibilities.

1.3. Data and access to information systems will be restricted to those who require access to undertake their role and who have been granted explicit authority to view and change information via Trust approved hardware to where it is required.
1.4. Any unauthorised use, or abuse, of the Trust telecommunications systems may be determined as a breach of this policy and subject to disciplinary proceedings.
Scope

2.1. This policy applies to employees, contractors, business consultants, temporaries, and other workers, including all personnel affiliated with third parties of Mid Essex Hospital NHS Trust, Southend University Hospital NHS Foundation Trust, and Basildon and Thurrock University Hospitals NHS Foundation Trust.

2.2. This policy applies to all Trust devices and systems which includes but is not limited to: desktop phones, mobile phones, phones issued as contingency devices or for individual/team use, bleeps, pagers and emergency radios.

2.3. The purpose of this policy is to inform all staff of the technical and operational security measures that the IT Department will employ in protecting the Trust from potential threats and misuse of Trust owned assets and to ensure staffs are aware of their managerial and operational responsibilities.
2.4. This document will outline the measures that the IT Department will implement in support of the following principals;
The Trust's information systems are properly assessed for security;
Confidentiality, Integrity and availability are maintained;
Staff are aware of their responsibility, roles and accountability; and
Procedures to detect and resolve security breaches are in place

data.text: Responsibilities
4.1. Role & Responsibilities within the Trust (Committees)
4.1.1. Digital Services Governance Group – to review policies and recommend for group approval.
4.1.2. Emergency Preparedness and Business Continuity Committee – to ensure that there are robust processes and policies in place.
4.1.3. Joint Document Ratification Group – to ratify polices
4.2. Role & Responsibilities of Individuals within the Trust
4.2.1. The Chief Executive as the Trust's Accountable Officer has ultimate responsibility for compliance with legal requirements and achievement of standards of best practice and will ensure:
Appropriate delegation of risk management and confidentiality management functions to a Director or equivalent;
Adequate resources to support effective information governance;
Submission of the annual Data Security and Protection Toolkit compliance self- assessment
4.2.2. Senior Information Risk Officer (SIRO) – Joint Executive Group (JEG) appointed Chief Information Officer responsible for ensuring:
Serious information risk management issues are brought to the Board for decision as required.
A lead or manager is in place to organise and enforce the Group's approach to information risk management.
Written advice is provided to the Accountable Officer and appropriate Trust Boards regarding the information risk management content of the annual report and Statement of Internal Control (SIC).
4.2.3. Caldicott Guardian Board appointed Site Director for each Trust is responsible for:
Protecting the confidentiality of PCD processed by the Trust, ensuring that all sites satisfy the highest practical standards for handling PCD.
Acting as the “conscience” of the Trust, by actively supporting work to enable use and sharing of PCD where this is appropriate and advising on lawful and ethical solutions.
Championing confidentiality and information sharing requirements and issues at Board level and, where appropriate, at a range of levels within the Trust's overall governance framework.
4.2.4. Clinical Directors (CD's) / Associate Clinical Directors (ACDs) and Head Nurses – as senior leaders at each Trust they have responsibility for:
Acting as Information Asset Owners (IAO) for systems within their local area of management.
Compliance with the requirements of this policy within their local area of management.
Ensuring staff within their management remit undertake mandatory information governance and other relevant training.
Overseeing the reporting of breaches of this policy resulting in information security or health and safety incidents on Trust incident reporting system.
Overseeing the investigation of reported breaches of this policy, making sure lessons learned are shared and appropriate changes in practice are implemented.
4.2.5. Director of Human Resources - has responsibility for ensuring:
That all staff contracts include appropriate clauses to maintain confidentiality.
That the Trust's training programme (induction and statutory) includes the appropriate information governance training and that all staff undergo this training.
There are robust leavers' procedures in place to enable the removal of system access rights in a timely manner.
Disciplinary procedures are conducted, which may be invoked should breaches in information security arise
4.2.6. Head of Digital Services, MSB Group
Operational responsibility for ensuring the development and revision of IT Policies and management of supporting Infrastructure.
4.2.7. Head of Information Governance, MSB Group
Operational responsibility for information governance across the MSB Group.
4.2.8. Cyber Security Officer, MSB Group
Operational responsibility for cyber security across the MSB Group.
4.2.9. Managers responsible for Switchboard Operations
Ensure all aspects of switchboard operations are performed in accordance with this policy and internal operating procedures.
Ensure that all staff are adequately trained and remain updated with any changes in procedure in order to carry out duties.
Ensure effective controls are in place relating to the reporting and logging processes.
Notify the MSB lead for Telephony if there are any incidents or issues pertaining to the use and function of the telecommunications services.
Reporting incidents via the Trust's risk management / incident reporting process.
Ensuring that operators update staff contact information, in a timely manner, when notified of changes and amendments.
4.2.10. Line Managers
Responsible for ensuring that staff are aware of this policy that they adhere to it and for managing issues which arise when staff fail to comply.
Ensuring that all current and future staff are instructed in their responsibilities;

Implementing procedures to minimise the Trust's exposure to fraud/theft/disruption of its systems or equipment, such as segregation of duties/dual control/staff rotation in critical/susceptible areas;
4.2.11. Trust Staff
Responsible for implementing and complying with the policy within the areas of their responsibility or control.
Responsible for being aware of what threats might be targeted via E-mail or other methods i.e. phone calls, social engineering etc. and reporting any suspicious activity to the IT Service Desk.
Responsible for ensuring that switchboard are made aware of any contact information changes or inaccuracies in order to ensure that the information held by switchboard remains accurate.
Policy Requirements
5.1. Communication Systems Available
5.1.1. Digital Telephony (VOIP)
Digital telephony, also known as Voice Over IP (VoIP) telephony, are services are available at Mid Essex & Southend and partially available at Basildon.
5.1.2. Analogue Telephony

Analogue telephones are deployed at Mid Essex for business continuity and backup purposes to allow clinicians and staff to maintain critical communications in the event of a network or failure of the VOIP system and also in corridor locations
The majority of telephones at Basildon are analogue phones
Analogue phones are very limited in availability at Southend
5.1.3. Mobile Phones
Mobile phones are available to all trust staff if they have a valid reason for use
5.1.4. Corridor Phones

Corridor phones are sited at various locations for staff convenience, the numbers of the corridor phones will be maintained in the directory so switchboard staff can cross reference the location in an emergency
Corridor phones will be limited to internal calls only and switchboard staff should not allow access to an external line
5.1.5. Bleeps

Bleeps (Internal pagers) are available at all three sites and should be used for clinical and critical internal communications. They do not work externally. Bleeps are also used for summoning emergency response teams such as the crash team.
5.1.6. Pagers

Pagers (External pagers) are available at all three sites and should be used for non-critical communication where a mobile phone us deemed not suitable. Staff should be aware that sending a page does not assure that the pager holder has received it and there can be a delay on transmission of pages
5.1.7. Automated & Call Management Solutions

There are solutions deployed across all our sites and facilities that provide supplemental functionality Automated attendant solution implemented for incoming calls to Switchboard at Mid Essex and Basildon. It utilises speech recognition to allow callers to identify who they wish to speak to without the need for direct contact with Switchboard staff.

Queue Management solutions can be used in areas where only one person is likely to be answering and/or busy departments where the ability to answer is out-paced by incoming call volume; both scenarios can lead to poor patient experience and is a potential source of complaint.
Patient Reminders – Text and voice solutions to remind patients of forth coming appointments
Call Centre Technology – Services designed to facilitate a telecoms solution in a call centre environment.
All of the solutions above allow service managers to monitor operational and individuals performance.
5.1.8. Radios

The trust have a number of radios which are held in specified locations and deployed as a contingency for emergency teams in the event of any infrastructure failure that impacts the telephone and/or bleep systems.
5.1.9. Voice Mail
Voicemail is provided at users or departmental request.
Voicemails must be monitored each working day and must not to be used as a means of avoiding answering the telephone and not returning calls.

Where departments and areas receive high call numbers users are advised to review voicemail boxes more frequently in order to prevent significant backlogs building; if backlogs continue to occur users are advised to contact the Telecoms team to discuss the implementation of a call centre solution.
Voicemail messages should be cleared within 48 hours.
5.1.11. Fixed Line Services & Broadband Services
There are various services that have fixed analogue lines including alarms and lift phones.
Fixed lines will only be procured and facilitated by the telecoms staff as detailed records are kept identifying all external telecommunications connections into our sites.
5.1.11.  Faxes
All devices that have the ability to send and received faxed information must be used in accordance with current Trust guidance.

Hard copy (traditional) machines have mainly are being withdrawn in favour of multi-function devices and electronic solutions, such as RightFax, in order to reduce not only unnecessary printing and line costs but also information governance risks associated with data being picked up by other individuals.
Some contingency safe-haven devices have been retained.
5.2. Allocation & Administration of Devices
5.2.1. New Devices
Any request for new equipment or telecoms services must be made via the Digital Services service desk and a call logged to support the request

The telecoms department will require a business and/or clinical justification for any additional equipment requested and any request for equipment that does not have a supporting reason that supports the business or patient safety will be rejected.
All requests for new equipment require a budget code and approval by a budget holder of the requesting department
5.2.2. Loss or theft of devices

Loss or Theft of any Trust device, regardless of whether it contains Person Identifiable Information (PII) or other sensitive information, is treated seriously and must be reported as soon as possible and an appropriate incident report raised

Where a bleep or pager is lost or mislaid the user should inform switchboard immediately. If the bleep/pager is for on-call or emergency purposes a replacement will be issued and the department charged the costs of a replacement device.
Where a Trust mobile phone is lost, mislaid or stolen, the following steps should be taken:
As soon as a mobile is found to be lost or mislaid, the user must inform the IT Service Desk immediately, or site office if out of hours, regarding the circumstances.
If a device is stolen from Trust premises, staff must firstly contact the Trust Security Team so they can report the device as stolen, and then the IT Service desk.

If a device is stolen whilst off Trust premises, the member of staff must contact the police immediately and report the device as stolen, they should then contact the Trust Security Team and then the IT Service desk providing the police crime reference number.

When calling the IT Service Desk users must inform the call handler if there was any personal/patient identifiable data located on the device. They should also state if it was password protected in order to determine whether the risk of accessing the device and its contents is reportable as a Serious Incident internally and to the ICO.
If the device is subsequently found, the IT Service Desk must be informed immediately.
When the Trust receives notification of a lost or stolen device, where the capability exists the device will be wiped remotely.
It should be noted that the loss, misplacement or theft of a mobile does not automatically warrant a replacement being issued. A decision to replace a mobile will be made on a case-by-case basis.
5.2.3. Bleeps/Pagers and Mobile Phones for On-Call Teams
Centralised lists of numbers for each of the on-call teams are held by the Switchboard teams at each site.

Bleeps ,pagers and mobile phones for On Call teams that are no longer used should be returned to switchboard for reallocation. Devices that have had minimal usage for three months will be reviewed and potentially recalled.
It is preferred that bleeps and pagers are issued for on-call/baton working rather than individual allocation in order to make best use of available assets.
5.3. Management of Communications Systems
5.3.1. Testing and Audit
Tests will be carried out at each site to ensure that the devices deployed for emergency / business continuity use are tested for availability on a monthly basis.

The results of these tests will be reviewed and where there are repeated instances of non-compliance this will be investigated to rule out technical issues with the equipment. Where there is no evidence of technical issues non- compliance will be raised to the Emergency Planning Officer and appropriate department head/lead for intervention.
5.3.2. Call Logging & Recording

The Trust is able to report upon call activity that is managed by its telephony systems for financial and performance purposes. These systems are also able to support the detection and investigation of potential  fraudulently activity, and other investigatory purposes.
Where voice recording or monitoring of calls is undertaken, both parties will be informed by means of publicity, verbal or audible warnings.

Voice recording will only be undertaken in those situations where it is necessary to archive the content of the call in order to provide a record for any subsequent investigation, analysis of an incident or training purposes.
5.3.3. Requesting Call Log Information

The use and access to any information held on individual telephone calls, such as telephone call logging data, voice recordings or personal call usage must be restricted to a limited number of key personnel who have a legitimate reason to request it.

Any data associated with personal calls, or that of a private and confidential nature, should be handled under the rules of the Regulation of Investigatory Power Act 2000 and in line with Trust Information Security Policies.

Managers can request call log reports for the purpose of any subsequent investigation or analysis of an incident by contacting the IT Service desk at Mid Essex and Basildon or by sending a completed Request for Information Form (TR015), to the Switchboard Manager at Southend which must be supported by an approval from the relevant HR manager if for the purposes of staff investigations
All information requests will be reviewed against GDPR principles, where there is ambiguity clarification will be sought from the Group Head of Information Governance.
5.5. Call Categories
5.4.1. Personal Calls

The Telephony solutions (including mobile phones) are provided for the purposes of conducting Trust business. Use for personal reasons, either making or receiving phone calls, should be limited to reasonable use only. The Trust reserves the right to recover any costs, incurred due to personal use, through the monitoring of the invoices.
Where excessive, inappropriate or unreasonable use of Trust resources is identified disciplinary action may be taken.
5.4.2. Conference Services
There are a number of companies that supply rd party call conference services. The preferred solution across the three trusts is Skype. For staff who wish to
make use of the facility should raise a call with the service desk in the st instance. Staff should minimise the use of other conference solutions and be
aware that calling 3rd part conference numbers often incurs a premium charge.
5.4.3. International Calls
Calls to international numbers from internal phones are required to go via Switchboard unless approved by Telecoms Manager (? Title)

Logs will be kept of all international calls made; users may be asked to provide the reason for the call and the name of their line manager or senior manager on shift that has approved the call if they are not a budget holder.
5.4.4. Calls to Directory Enquiries
Calls to Directory Enquiries are not permitted, instead staff are encouraged to use telephone directories or to search online directories such as www.bt.com and www.yell.com.
5.4.5. Calls to switchboard

Automated Voice systems and directories have been deployed to minimise switchboard calls and staff should not be using switchboard unless they have a valid reason. The switchboard staff may challenge staff who have not used other reasonable means to avoid calling them.
5.4.6. Premium Charge Numbers
Calls to premium rate numbers are not permitted unless previously approved by the Telecoms manager
5.4.7. Cardiac Arrest (Crash Calls) or Emergency Calls

In line with Trust emergency response protocols, callers should calm and state the nature of the emergency. Callers are required to state the ward/department and location of the emergency then remain silent until the Operator repeats all the details.

5.5. Receiving Calls
5.5.1. Patient Experience & Customer Service

Calls dealt with at any point in the Trust's telecommunications infrastructure should have a clear objective as to time taken to respond to them and the quality of greeting given. Operator response times should be clear and concise and monitored from time to time.

The speed and efficiency with which telephone calls are answered and dealt with create a direct impression of the efficiency of the Trust as a whole. There are industry accepted guidelines for telephone response times and the Trust expects these to be met. Whilst these response times are aimed at the Telephonist function, they should also be the target for all staff receiving telephone calls especially reception areas.
5.5.2. Call Handling Standards
It is important to demonstrate common courtesy and portray a professional approach to verbal communication.

The importance of voice communications performance is paramount and critical to the efficient performance of the Trust. It has been recognised there is a need to have a standard approach to answering the telephone. This approach should apply to both external and internal calls.
When responding to incoming calls staffs are expected to :
Be approachable
Have a genuine responsive manner
Have an empathic attitude
Consider their tone: not hurried or brisk but warm and approachable
5.5.4. Threatening / Abusive calls
Persistent threatening / abusive behaviour from any persons (patients or staff) is not acceptable and will not be tolerated.
Any member of staff who receives a threatening / abusive telephone call should:
Politely ask the person to stop, and warn them that if their behaviour is not modified it may be necessary to end the call
If the behaviour persists, you should bring the call to an end by letting the caller know that you are going to hang up
Hang up
Inform your Line Manager or Director immediately
Write up details of the call and pass to your Line Manager or Director who may escalate to the Trust Local Security Manager.
5.6. Potential Threats
5.6.1. Malicious attacks against organisations are increasing and have made the news headlines on a number of occasions in the last twelve months.
5.6.2. Attacks may be un-targeted or targeted via various routes including emails and SMS text messages;
5.6.3. Social engineering is an increasing risk to an organisation's security by exploiting people (staff) instead of electronic of physical weaknesses. Such attacks can be:
External telephone calls from someone claiming to be from another NHS organisation or someone claiming to be a patient or a member of their family (Vishing);
Telephone calls asking if a certain doctor or staff member works in your department.
Unusual Email messages looking as if they were sent from someone in the Trust (a colleague or the IT Department) asking you to visit a website, run a programme or click on a link.
5.6.4. Before giving out any information over the telephone, always check the source. For instance:
Offer to phone a patient or NHS organisation back using their registered telephone number
Staff must call the Local Security Manager if they receive any suspicious calls or have any concerns
5.7. Abuse of Policy
5.7.1.  Any member of staff that contravenes this policy, or related policies, may be subject to disciplinary proceedings, verbal or written warning and potential termination of employment.
5.8. Business Continuity
5.8.1. Business Continuity Plans are owned and maintained by Operational areas for all critical Trust systems.
5.8.2. Staff should refer to their local Trust business continuity plans in the event of a telephony or mobile communications failure.

5.8.3. Any changes arising from the implementation of new telephony or communications systems will be developed in partnership with the Emergency Planning Officer and will be reflected in this policy and/or business continuity plans where appropriate.
5.9. Physical Securing of Equipment
5.9.1.  Where equipment is located in a vulnerable location, physical security measures should be implemented as appropriate to ensure its continued unhindered operation.
Training Requirements
6.1. Staff are required to complete IG training as part of their annual mandatory training obligations
6.2. Between annual training requirements staff are to ensure that they keep up to date regarding IT or Cyber security update emails and messages published in staff circulars.
6.3. If there are any concerns regarding the content or implications of this policy they should be directed to the IT Service Desk.
Monitoring & Audit
Compliance to this policy will be monitored as follows:
